intro: Hydrobryopsis, commonly known as the water gemmule, is a type of moss that belongs to the family Pottiaceae. It is characterized by its small, compact growth form and ability to survive in moist, shaded environments. The plant produces spores in capsules that are often protected by a peristome, a specialized structure that aids in spore dispersal. Hydrobryopsis is known for its resilience, as it can endure periods of desiccation and rehydrate when moisture returns. Its simple morphology and ecological adaptability make it a common component of many moist, temperate habitats.
